docs.lead_paragraph: A New York Times/CBS News poll finds the individual mandate at the heart of opposition to the law.

headline.main: Most Oppose at Least Part of Overhaul, Poll Finds
headline.print_headline: Most Oppose at Least Part of Overhaul, Poll Finds

docs.abstract: New York Times/CBS News poll finds that two-thirds of Americans want the Supreme Court to overturn some or all of the health care law, even though large majorities support a few of its major aspects; at heart of the opposition is the individual mandate requiring Americans to obtain health insurance.
docs.snippet: A New York Times/CBS News poll finds the individual mandate at the heart of opposition to the law.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

byline.contributor: Marjorie Connelly and Marina Stefan contributed reporting.
byline.original: By DALIA SUSSMAN, HELENE COOPER and KATE PHILLIPS

docs.lead_paragraph: An experimental drug that works in a novel way to lower cholesterol proved even more effective than statins and had few side effects, according to newly released data.

headline.seo: Drug to Cut Cholesterol Level Tests Better Than Statins
headline.main: Drug to Cut Cholesterol Tests Better Than Statin
headline.print_headline: Drug to Cut Cholesterol Tests Better Than Statin

docs.abstract: Studies by Dr Evan A Stein in The New England Journal of Medicine find that REGN727, an experimental drug that works in a novel way to lower cholesterol, is more effective than statins and has few undesirable side effects.
docs.snippet: An experimental drug that works in a novel way to lower cholesterol proved even more effective than statins and had few side effects, according to newly released data.

docs.lead_paragraph: Bariatric surgery, in which the stomach is stapled and the small intestine rerouted, puts the disease into remission far more often than drugs, diet and exercise, researchers say.

headline.seo: To Combat Diabetes, Weight Loss Surgery Works Better Than Medicine, Studies Find
headline.main: Surgery for Diabetes May Be Better Than Standard Treatment
headline.print_headline: Surgery Is Found To Aid Diabetics

docs.abstract: Two studies, published in The New England Journal of Medicine, find that obese and overweight people who undergo weight-loss operations, like bariatric surgery, are more likely to have complete remission of Type 2 diabetes than people given non-surgical treatment; some surgeons and obesity experts are now pushing to establish a role for the surgeries in treating diabetes, not just obesity, while other experts, concerned over the risks and complications inherent in major surgery, say more research is needed.
docs.snippet: Bariatric surgery, in which the stomach is stapled and the small intestine rerouted, puts the disease into remission far more often than drugs, diet and exercise, researchers say.

docs.lead_paragraph: More than 40 million American adults already take an aspirin a day to prevent heart disease. Now many more are weighing the pros and cons of daily aspirin use in light of new studies finding that it also may reduce the risk of many cancers and stop the spread of tumors. Six months ago Vanessa Brannan, a 31-year-old Seattle mother of two, learned she had colon cancer and Lynch syndrome, an inherited condition that increases risk of the disease and other cancers. Some of the best data on aspirin's effectiveness against cancer has been found in patients like Mrs. Brannan. In one British study, patients with Lynch syndrome who took aspirin for two years cut their risk of colon cancer in half.

headline.main: The Consumer: How Much Aspirin Is Too Much of a Good Thing?

docs.abstract: More than 40 million American adults take an aspirin a day to prevent heart disease, and the number is expanding in light of recent studies showing that it may reduce the risk of many cancers; science of understanding the relationship between aspirin and cancer remains in its infancy, and doctors remain sharply divided over what is the most effective dosage. Photo (M)

headline.main: How Much Aspirin Is Too Much of a Good Thing?
headline.print_headline: The Consumer: How Much Aspirin Is Too Much of a Good Thing?

docs.abstract: Despite recent good news about aspirin reducing the risk of cancers, doctors still don't know how much of it people should take.
docs.snippet: Despite recent good news about aspirin reducing the risk of cancers, doctors still don't know how much of it people should take.

docs.lead_paragraph: The risks of sleeping pills are real, but so are the risks of sleep deprivation.
docs.abstract: Gray Matter column by Gayle Greene cautions against studies that have found that sleeping pills are dangerous; reflects on her own experience as an insomiac; argues while the risks of sleeping pills are real, so are the risks of sleep deprivation.
docs.snippet: The risks of sleeping pills are real, but so are the risks of sleep deprivation.

headline.main: Robert Bales and the Case for a Measured Approach to Alcohol in Combat

docs.abstract: Would an alcohol policy based on rationing, rather than restriction, accompanied by illicit use and binging, have made a difference in the case of Staff Sgt. Robert Bales?
docs.snippet: Would an alcohol policy based on rationing, rather than restriction, accompanied by illicit use and binging, have made a difference in the case of Staff Sgt. Robert Bales?
